Posts.Content: Apr 14, 2007 12:36PM Made wrote: Abnormal mammogram after 5 normal mammograms - no lumps, no bleeding - totally surprised. Based on ultrasound - radiologist scheduled a biopsy same day and told me that even if it came back inconclusive she'd send me to the Breast Surgical Oncologist. Biopsy came back IDC and DCIS 7mm, er/pr+, her2 -, grade 1., lumpectomy and mammosite radiology.
Posts.Title: How were you diagnosed? Symptoms/Signs, etc? greenacres nelia48

Posts.Content: Feb 23, 2007 12:25AM Made wrote: I'm premenopausal and my oncologist recommended the oncotype test. One of the reasons she ordered it was my age (45) and my KI-67 was high. So ask if these would be contributing factors. I too am IDC but my oncotype test came back low risk of reoccurence so no chemo here.

Posts.Title: Why am I not upset? Barbara1 Mary-Lou

Posts.Content: May 26, 2007 07:13PM Made wrote: Pat - Medicare pays for the oncotype test - good luck on the appeals - aren't the genotype folks just great. There's the possiblity that you will qualify for financial aid if denied 3 times.
Posts.Title: Oncotype Test Dkissel san4850

Posts.Content: Oct 20, 2007 12:57PM - edited Oct 20, 2007 12:58PM by Made Barbara First I'm sorry to welcome you to the club but if your worried about how you are handling it - stop it.  We all processed that same information in very different ways.  For me - it was ok - it was bad news - now whats the best way to handle this - how do I tell my kids (they are young 15, 13, and 5), how do I tell my parents and what are my treatment options. Did I stay in this positive mode - heck no - cried in the shower several times and then 4 or 5 months post treatment - cried to Craig Morgan's song Tough more times than I want to admit.  Figure out that for me -while in the mode of deciding treatment and getting the news out was a safe time.  It was that down time after that was dangerous.  However, I'm 10 months post diagnosis and doing great.  How you deal with this is totally up to you and there is no wrong way - just your way!! Hugs Kelly
Posts.Title: Why am I not upset? Barbara1 Mary-Lou

Posts.Content: Apr 7, 2007 07:55PM Made wrote: I can't imagine saying no to a SNB - positive or negative nodes changes the treatment plans so drastically. Keep in mind what you are reading here is antidotal and those with no side effects from it probably don't even post. I had 3 nodes removed after receiving an injection of something that allowed the nuclear machine to mark my SNBs. My Breast Surgeon didn't even need a 2nd incision to remove. I've had absolutely no side effects from the SNB. I do treat my right arm (right breast - idc and dcis) as a breast cancer arm and don't allow blood draws or blood pressure readings but other than that it works just as hard as my left. I am almost 3 months post op.
Posts.Title: Deciding no to a SNB? climbergirl lvtwoqlt

Posts.Content: Apr 15, 2007 06:06PM Made wrote: Her breast is still recovering from the surgery - mine was 'lumpy' up until recently and I had a lumpectomy January 18th - but than started radiation 2 weeks later. The dimple is just from the incision pulling - I had a horrible skin tag for a few weeks. Hugs and hope this information helps.

God forbid its not B9 then a week won't matter and if its is B9(praying that is so) you'll deserve a vacation.
